content.title: Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome
content.description: Compression of the subclavian artery at the thoracic outlet, typically associated with cervical rib or anomalous first rib, leading to arterial injury, aneurysm formation, and distal embolization.
content.epidemiology: Rarest TOS variant (1-5%), often associated with cervical rib (85%), younger patients
content.pathophysiology: Repetitive arterial trauma from bony abnormality leads to intimal injury, post-stenotic dilation, aneurysm formation, mural thrombus, and distal embolization.
clinical_presentation: Weakened radial pulse with arm elevation

treatment.surgical_indication: All cases with arterial complications require surgery
treatment.approach: Supraclavicular with clavicle preservation or resection

content.statement: Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Thoracic-Outlet that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
